Fig. 1 The SEM, TEM images, EDS mapping and particle size distributions of 1 V/MSN (A, E, I), 2 V/MSN (B, F, J), 3 V/MSN (C, G, K) and 8 V/MSN (D, H, L) catalysts; The schematic diagram for the formation mechanism of V/MSN catalysts (M). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (A) and Raman spectra (B) of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Deconvoluted H2-TPR curves of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The XPS spectra of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Deconvoluted UV-Vis DR spectra of dehydrated V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Methane conversion and product selectivity distribution as a function of temperature for V/MSN catalysts of different V contents. Reaction conditions: 0.05 g catalyst, CH4: O2: N2 = 2: 1: 3, total gas flow rate 60 mL/min. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Yield of formaldehyde (A), TOF of methane consumption (B) and formaldehyde formation (C) as a function of temperature over V/MSN catalysts; A plot of ln(TOFC2H4) on 1/RT over xV/MSN catalysts for the selective oxidation of methane (D). Selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde and carbon monoxide over V/MSN catalysts with isolated VO4 sites Jiaxin Song Writing – original draft Formal analysis a b Jing Cui Software Formal analysis a 1 Xin Gao Visualization Software a Xiaoqiang Fan Writing – review & editing Data curation a ⁎ Xuehua Yu Visualization Resources a Lian Kong Validation Supervision a Xia Xiao Supervision Software a Zean Xie Visualization Validation a Zhen Zhao Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a b ⁎⁎ a Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034, China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034, China b State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034, China. Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work The selective oxidation of methane to value-added C1 chemicals (e.g., HCHO and CO) is a crucial process in the chemical industry. Recent studies indicate that the generation of highly dispersed isolated active sites is crucial for improving the performance in the selective oxidation of methane and studying the corresponding structure–activity relationship. Therefore, we used mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN) as supports and utilized grafting method to prepare catalysts with more selective oxidation active centers (isolated VO4). The study found that isolated VO4 centers are the active sites for the selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde, and CO is the product of further oxidation of formaldehyde. The total selectivity of formaldehyde and CO on all catalysts is higher than 83.6 %. Among them, the highly dispersed and isolated VO4 tetrahedral active centers on the 2 V/MSN catalyst could stably convert methane to formaldehyde, achieving the highest formaldehyde yield of 3.7 % at 670 °C. Graphical Abstract Keywords Selective oxidation of methane Formaldehyde Catalysts VO4 active sites Organometallic grafting method Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde is a formidable challenge in modern chemistry, and the formaldehyde product is an important precursor for many valuable compounds, this process has attracted considerable research interest [1–3]. The challenge to the direct conversion of methane comes from the high energy of the H–CH3 bond (438.9 kJ mol−1), due to the high symmetry of methane molecules. Thus, the CH4 activation usually requires high temperatures; moreover, because the oxidation products are usually more reactive than methane, the conditions required to activate the C–H bonds of methane result in a loss of selectivity toward the total oxidation products [4,5]. Therefore, the selective oxidation of CH4 to products such as methanol, formaldehyde, and carbon monoxide without CO2 emissions is a challenging task [6–9]. Various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed to activate the C–H bonds of methane [10–12]. Catalysts supported on metal oxides (such as Mo/ZrO2) and silicon-based materials (such as V/SiO2, Mo/SiO2, and Co/SiO2) [13–15], as well as composite metal oxide catalysts such as BiPO4 and Ce1−xZrxO2 [16,17], have been developed for the selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. Among these catalysts, those containing VOx and MoOx active components exhibit excellent catalytic activity. The inert SiO2 materials are more suitable as supports for VOx catalysts than their acidic or alkaline counterparts, and the SiO2 material not only weakens the strong metal–support interaction and improves the reducibility of the active metals, but also has a larger surface area that can achieve a better dispersion of active sites. Currently, the molecular structure of VOx species loaded on SiO2 typically includes dispersed monomeric VOx, low polymerized VOx, high polymerized VOx, and V2O5 crystallites. Among them, the highly dispersed VOx species are considered as the active sites for the selective oxidation of methane [18–21]. Lin et al. [22] found that the VOx/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited better performances in the selective oxidation of methane than Mo and W oxide- loaded SBA-15. Characterization studies revealed that the highly dispersed VOx species are beneficial for the selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. Loricera and Yang et al. [23,24] also reported that the presence of highly dispersed and isolated tetrahedral VOx species is beneficial for improving the formaldehyde selectivity in the selective oxidation of methane, while aggregated or crystalline VOx species promote the formaldehyde conversion to CO2. In other words, highly dispersed active metal oxide species are necessary for the selective formation of formaldehyde. In order to develop efficient catalysts for the selective oxidation of methane, previous studies have explored different methods to improve the dispersion of active components. Carrero et al. conducted in-depth research on this topic and found that the preparation method of catalysts, the selection of support, and the V content on the surface of catalyst are the main factors affecting the dispersion of VOx species [25,26]. The most commonly used method to achieve this goal is to replace SiO2 with mesoporous SiO2 with large surface area and well-ordered pore structure as the support [27–30]. Therefore, in order to improve the dispersion of active components on the catalyst, mesoporous silica nanoparticle prepared by the emulsion method were used as support. Introducing the VOx active centers into the MSN harnesses their characteristics, such as high specific surface area, uniform particle size, and easy molecular diffusion, to form a mesoporous silica-supported VOx catalyst with highly dispersed and isolated active sites. The difficulty in controlling the active site structure of catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation methods makes it challenging to study their structure–activity relationships. In this work, an organometallic grafting method was used to prepare the catalysts with highly dispersed active sites using the VO(acac)2 precursor, and the content of supported transition metal V was varied to regulate the degree of polymerization of VOx species in the catalyst. In order to study the physical and chemical properties of V/MSN catalysts and identify their relationship with their performance in the selective oxidation of methane. The catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, H2-TPR, X-ray-photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV-Vis DRS, isothermal isotopic oxygen exchange, CH4-temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR), and in situ Raman experiments. The results showed that the active components of V/MSN catalysts with different V amounts prepared by the grafting method existed in the form of isolated VO4 centers, as well as highly dispersed oligomeric VOx species. The presence of isolated VO4 species resulted in a total selectivity of more than 83.6 % for formaldehyde and CO on all catalysts within the reaction temperature range investigated in this work. The isolated VO4 species in the 2 V/MSN catalyst achieved high selectivity for formaldehyde, with a maximum yield of 3.7 % at 670 °C. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation MSN were prepared by oil-water microemulsion assembly approach [31]. First, an aqueous solution of hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide with 0.15 mol/L concentration was added to 36 mL (0.13 mol/L) of ammonium bicarbonate solution to form a homogeneous mixture. Then, 16 mL of cyclohexane and 2 mL of isopropanol were added to the mixed solution. Afterward, 3.74 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate were rapidly added to the mixed solution and the reaction was continued at 70 °C. The prepared sample was filtered and dried in 80 °C overnight, followed by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain the MSN support. V/MSN catalysts were prepared by the grafting method. A certain amount of VO(acac)2, employed as the vanadium source, was added to a toluene solution; then, an appropriate amount of MSN support was added and stirred for 24 h. The sample was washed 3–4 times with toluene solution and dried at 80 °C and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain the xV/MSN catalysts, where x denotes the loading amounts of transition metal V (1, 2, 3, and 8 wt%). In particular, x represents the integer part of the actual mass fraction of the V element, as measured by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) experiments. Furthermore, the as-prepared fresh samples were used for subsequent characterization. 2.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity The reaction for selective oxidation of methane was tested in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor. Fill the sample (40–60 mesh, 0.05 g) into the reactor and measure the reaction temperature by inserting a thermocouple into the catalyst bed. The methane, oxygen, and nitrogen were co-fed into the reactor by three calibrated mass ﬂow controllers. The composition of the reactants and products was analyzed online by an Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph, equipped with two TCDs and one flame ionization detector (FID). C2H6 and C2H4 in the components were detected by the FID, while CH4, CO, CO2, and HCHO were detected by the two TCDs. No carbon deposition was observed on the surface of catalyst, and the carbon balance was ensured to be greater than 97 %. The catalytic performance in the selective oxidation of methane was calculated as follows: Conversion of methane % = the total amount of products amount of methane in feedstock × 100 Selectivity of product Pi % = amount of Pi in products total amount of products × 100 Yield of product Pi % = conversion of methane × selectivity of product Pi × 100 where Pi = HCHO, C2H4, C2H6, CO, CO2. TOF CH 4 s − 1 = F ( CH 4 )× 0.001 × M M × X CH 4 60 × 22.4 × m cat × W M × 100 TOF HCHO s − 1 = F ( CH 4 )× 0.001 × M M × Y HCHO 60 × 22.4 × m cat × W M × 100 X CH 4 is the conversion of methane, YHCHO is the yield of formaldehyde in the product, and N represents the carbon number of the product. Moreover, F(CH4) is the total flow rate of CH4 in the feed gas (20 mL/min), TOF represents the rate of methane consumption or formaldehyde generation per unit time at a single metal atomic site (s−1), MM denotes the relative atomic mass of the metal, mcat is the mass of the catalyst, and WM is the mass fraction of the metal in the catalyst measured by ICP-MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical structure analysis of V/MSN catalysts To measure the efficiency of the grafting method and obtain the actual V loading amounts, the results of the ICP characterization of the V/MSN catalysts are listed in Table 1. At low grafting contents (x ≤ 2), although the actual content was lower than the theoretical values, the grafting efficiency could exceed 80 %. However, the grafting efficiency decreased with increasing grafting amount. Therefore, two-step grafting was used to prepare high-loading catalysts, and the 8 V/MSN catalyst was obtained by repeated grafting based on the 3 V/MSN catalyst. Although the actual loading amount of V was lower than the corresponding theoretical amount, the grafting method could successfully load most of the metals on the surface of the support. SEM and TEM characterizations can provide detailed information on the surface morphology and microstructure of catalysts, and are widely used to analyze the microstructural morphology of nanomaterials. Fig. 1 shows the SEM, TEM, and EDS images of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. The SEM images show that the V/MSN catalysts had a porous dendritic nanosphere structure, which is beneficial for improving the dispersion of VOx species on the catalyst surface, reducing heat accumulation on it and inhibiting the deep oxidation of methane. Furthermore, the resolution of the porous surface structure of the V/MSN catalysts decreased with the increasing of V loading, which may be due to a higher number of VOx species entering the interior of the pores and changing the pore structure of the catalyst. The particle size distribution shows that nanospheres with low V loading were uniformly distributed, and the range of particle size for the catalyst is approximately 110–130 nm. However, the uniformity of the nanospheres decreased for the 8 V/MSN catalyst, which may be due to the formation of partially polymerized VOx species on the catalyst surface. The TEM and EDS images of the V/MSN catalyst show that the content of surface VOx species gradually increased with increasing V content. However, even on the catalyst with the highest V loading (8 V/MSN), no vanadia particles with high polymerization degree were detected on the catalyst surface, indicating that VOx was highly dispersed on the catalyst surface prepared by the grafting method. To illustrate the structural/chemical composition and the synthesis process of the V/MSN catalysts, the schematic diagram for the formation process of V/MSN catalysts is show in Fig. 1M. Fig. S1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of different V/MSN catalysts. Fig. S1A reveals that catalysts with different V loading amounts exhibited a similar structure to the MSN, with a typical type IV adsorption–desorption isotherm and a H4 hysteresis loop, indicating that the introduction of V did not disrupt the mesoporous structure of the MSN. The pore size distribution of the catalyst was relatively uniform as shown in Fig. S1B, mainly concentrated between 2–3 and 5–25 nm. The distribution peak corresponding to 2–3 nm pore sizes decreased with increasing V content, which may be due to a higher number of VOx species entering the pores and covering the inner surface with increasing V loading, resulting in a change in the pore structure of the catalyst. Table 2 lists the textural properties of the catalyst calculated based on the N2 adsorption desorption isotherm. The decreases of the BET surface area and pore volume from 855 m2·g−1 and 1.60 cm3·g−1 for the MSN to 763 m2·g−1 and 1.24 cm3·g−1 for the 3 V/MSN catalyst, suggest that the VOx species entered the mesopores. However, the surface area and pore volume of the 8 V/MSN catalyst did not show a further significant decrease, indicating that no crystalline V2O5 species were formed at the highest V loading, which is consistent with the results of TEM characterization. The above results reveal that the high specific surface area and open pore structure of MSN support are conducive to the dispersion of active VOx components. To verify this conclusion, the surface density of V on catalysts with different V loading amounts was calculated (Table S1). It was found that the V surface density (0.2–1.3 V nm−2) of V/MSN samples synthesized by grafting method is very low, and significantly lower than the experimentally determined single-layer coverage [32]. Therefore, high formaldehyde selectivity was obtained on 1 V/MSN and 2 V/MSN catalysts. 3.2 Structural characterizations of V/MSN catalysts In order to study the crystalline structure of catalysts with different V loading amounts and dispersion degree of active components, Fig. 2A shows the XRD patterns of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. The XRD analysis shows that all V/MSN catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks corresponding to the amorphous SiO2 phase at 23.5° [33]. Nevertheless, no diffraction peaks related to V2O5 crystals were detected at 2θ = 20.1°, 26.1°, and 31.2° with increasing V content [34,35], even for the catalyst with the highest V loading amount (8 V/MSN), indicating the absence of large-sized (> 3 nm) V2O5 particles on the surface of catalyst. Further analysis was conducted using another surface-sensitive technique, Raman spectroscopy, owing to its ability to probe the local structure of oxides, especially those with poor crystallinity. The VOx species in the catalyst tend to react with H2O in air, which affects their coordination structure. Therefore, all catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C in a 2 % O2/N2 atmosphere for 30 min before testing, to ensure the accuracy of the coordination structure. Fig. 2B shows the Raman spectra of the V/MSN catalysts. The Raman bands at 470 cm−1 are attributed to the four-membered Si–O rings of the MSN support [36]. The stretching vibration band at 930 cm−1 corresponds to the V–O–V bonds of the oligomeric VOx species, and its strength slightly increased with increasing V content [37,38]. The VO stretching vibration band corresponding to isolated VOx species in tetrahedral coordination (VO4) was detected at 1030 cm−1 [39,40], and its strength did not show a significant change with increasing V loading. Moreover, no characteristic vibration bands at 703 and 995 cm−1 assigned to V2O5 species were found in the spectra of the samples, even in that of the 8 V/MSN catalyst [41,42]. The above results indicate that VO4 centers were the dominant VOx species in 1 V/MSN and 2 V/MSN catalysts. They consisted of VOx species in distorted tetrahedral coordination, with a short VO and three V–O bonds connecting them to the support. Although most VOx species in the 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts existed in VO4 form, some oligomeric V–O–V species were still present, consistent with the XRD and TEM results. H2-TPR experiments were performed to investigate the redox properties of the catalysts. The H2-TPR profiles of the V/MSN catalysts as show in Fig. 3. The reduction peak belonging to the isolated V5+ species in [VO4]3- was found in all samples at 460–475 °C [43–45]. For 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts, significant reduction peaks attributed to the reduction of oligomeric VOx species were observed at 500–550 °C, indicating an increase in the degree of polymerization of V species with increasing V loading [46,47]. However, no high-temperature reduction peak attributed to crystalline V2O5 was detected [48,49]. This confirms that highly dispersed and isolated VO4 were the dominant species in the V/MSN catalysts prepared by the grafting method, which is in agreement with the XRD and Raman spectra results. Fig. 4 shows the O 1 s XPS spectra of all samples, and the peak at ∼ 533 eV corresponded to the O atoms in SiO2. Furthermore, the BE signal at ∼ 530 eV was assigned to the lattice oxygen species (Olatt) [50,51]. The intensity of the lattice oxygen peak slowly increased with increasing V loading, but was still low for the catalyst with the highest V loading (8 V/MSN), this indicates that there was no significant aggregation of VOx species on the catalyst surface, consistent with the H2-TPR and Raman spectra characterizations. The UV-Vis DRS characterization can provide some information on the coordination structure of transition metals in the catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the UV-Vis DRS spectra of the V/MSN catalysts and the estimated percentages of different VOx species in the dehydrated samples. The positions of different bands corresponding to the O→V electronic transition of different VOx species provide a way to evaluate the state of these centers in the catalyst [52]. The band at approximately 260 nm could be attributed to highly dispersed and isolated VO4 species combined with oxygen atoms from tetrahedral silica [53]. The other absorption peaks at approximately 320 and 390 nm indicated the presence of higher coordinated Vδ+ ions in an octahedral environment [54]. Moreover, the proportion of highly dispersed tetrahedral VOx species (260 nm) decreased with increasing V loading, while the proportion of VOx species (320 nm) with a high polymerization degree increased. However, a significant content of highly dispersed tetrahedral VOx species was still present in the 8 V/MSN catalyst with the highest V loading, indicating a higher dispersion of VOx in the V/MSN catalysts prepared by the grafting method. Fig. 6 shows the acidity of the V/MSN catalysts examined in the NH3-TPD experiments. According to the temperature range in NH3-TPD patterns, the acid sites can be classified into three categories of weak (< 250 ° C), moderate (250–400 ° C), or strong (> 400 ° C) [55–57]. The NH3-TPD profiles of the V/MSN catalysts exhibited a desorption peak centered at 106–118 °C, indicating that the weak acid sites were dominant on the catalyst surface. The desorption peak area of the NH3-TPD profile significantly increased with the increasing of V grafting amount, which is in agreement with previous studies [58], suggesting a significant increase in the amount of weak acid sites. When the grafting amount of V was low (x ≤ 3), a desorption peak corresponding to medium acid sites was also observed at 400 °C. When the grafting amount of V reached its maximum, the corresponding desorption peak temperature shifted to a high value (450 °C), confirming the presence of some strong acid sites on the surface of the 8 V/MSN catalyst. The activity evaluation experiments indicated that excessive or strong acidities did not result in the formation of formaldehyde, which could facilitate the deep oxidation reaction. 3.3 Catalytic performance of V/MSN catalysts The relationships among the CH4 conversion and product selectivity distribution of V/MSN catalysts with different V contents and reaction temperatures are show in Fig. 7. The conversion of methane on V/MSN catalysts with different V loadings was directly proportional to the reaction temperature, and more significant differences were found between samples with different V contents. The conversion sharply increased with increasing temperature, especially for the catalysts with higher V loadings (3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN). All the catalysts achieved optimal methane conversion at 700 °C, increasing in the order 1 V/MSN (14.6 %) < 2 V/MSN (23.9 %) < 3 V/MSN (26.1 %) ≈ 8 V/MSN (26.2 %). The methane conversion gradually increased with increasing V loading for the 1 V/MSN, 2 V/MSN, and 3 V/MSN catalysts. In particular, the ability of the catalyst to activate methane increased with increasing V content within a certain V loading range. However, as the V loading was further increased, no significant difference was found between the methane conversions of the 8 V/MSN and 3 V/MSN catalysts, indicating a limited effect of the V loading on the methane activation ability of the catalysts. The selectivity toward target products is one of the important parameters characterizing the performance of a catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7, all catalysts achieved a high formaldehyde selectivity (> 86 %) at the lowest reaction temperature. The formaldehyde selectivity of the 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts decreased rapidly with increasing reaction temperature, while the selectivity of the formaldehyde for the catalysts with low V loading showed a slight increase with the descending V loadings, and the selectivity of formaldehyde for the catalysts with low V loadings were significantly higher than those of the 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts. Furthermore, it is very interesting that almost no CO was detected on any of the catalysts at lower temperatures, and the reaction products were mainly CO2 and formaldehyde. The CO2 selectivity remained almost unchanged with increasing reaction temperature. The decrease in formaldehyde selectivity was accompanied by a significant increase in CO selectivity, indicating that CO might be a secondary product of the further oxidation of formaldehyde or the decomposition of formaldehyde. The results of UV-Vis DRS characterization also confirmed the presence of different proportions of isolated VO4 and oligomeric VOx species in the catalysts. It can be speculated that the isolated VO4 species are the active sites of formaldehyde production, while the oligomeric VOx species are the active sites for CO2 generation. Moreover, a lower V loading resulted in a wider temperature window where only CO2 and formaldehyde coexisted, indicating that the formaldehyde produced on catalysts with lower V loading was more stable and less prone to undergo further oxidation to CO. This may further confirm that formaldehyde and CO were produced on the same active site, and the product of further oxidation or decomposition of formaldehyde was CO, rather than CO2. This may be due to the fact that the density of active sites is very low for the samples with low loading amounts. The number of isolated VO4 species increased with the increasing of V loading amount, which leads to a secondary reaction between the generated formaldehyde and the active sites (isolated VO4) on the catalyst surface to generate CO. Moreover, high temperatures also resulted in an increased probability of the secondary reaction. Therefore, the CO selectivity increased rapidly with increasing V loading and reaction temperature. For all catalysts, the total selectivity to formaldehyde and CO remained above 83.6 %, as shown in Table S2. As the temperature increased, the catalysts with high V content achieved a higher CO2 selectivity, but the highest value did not exceed 16.2 %. The 1 V/MSN catalyst achieved the highest formaldehyde selectivity of 91.2 % at 620 °C, and maintained a 22 % formaldehyde selectivity even at the highest temperature (700 °C). These results indicate that the V/MSN catalysts prepared by the grafting method contained more selective active sites (isolated VO4) for the formation of formaldehyde, and the catalysts with appropriate active site density could achieve better performance in the selective oxidation of CH4 to formaldehyde or CO. Meanwhile, the 2 V/MSN catalyst also maintained relatively high stability at 670 °C, as shown in Fig. S2. Moreover, repeated tests were conducted on 2 V/MSN catalyst to ensure their repeatability. The measurement results are presented in the form of error bars, as shown in Fig. S3, confirming the good repeatability of selective oxidation of methane activity for the catalyst. Fig. 8A shows the relationship between formaldehyde yield and temperature for V/MSN catalysts with different V contents. The formaldehyde yield of all catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped dependence on the temperature, and the temperature corresponding to the highest formaldehyde yield on all catalysts gradually decreased with the increasing of V loading amount. Furthermore, at low reaction temperatures (T < 610 °C), the formaldehyde yield of catalysts with lower V loading was significantly lower than that of the 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts, mainly because the former had a poor methane activation ability and lower methane conversion, resulting in a lower formaldehyde yield. However, the catalysts with low V loading maintained a high formaldehyde selectivity at high temperatures. Hence, the formaldehyde yield of the 1 V/MSN and 2 V/MSN catalysts was significantly higher than that of their 3 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN counterparts with increasing temperature, and the activity evaluation results of catalysts at high temperatures are greatly affected by gas-phase reactions. The maximum yield of the 2 V/MSN catalyst was 3.7 % at a temperature of 670 °C. Furthermore, the comparison of catalytic performance among V/MSN catalysts and catalysts prepared by other researchers was conducted (Table S3), and the results show that V/MSN catalysts have moderate activity for methane to formaldehyde when compared with those previously reported catalysts. Assuming that all V atoms in the catalyst are active sites for the selective oxidation of CH4, Fig. 8B and C show the TOF values of CH4 conversion and formaldehyde formation on a single vanadium atom of the V/MSN catalysts as a function of the temperature. As shown in Fig. 8B, the rate of formaldehyde formation showed an initial increase followed by a decrease with increasing temperature. Moreover, at lower V loadings, the temperature had a more significant effect on the formaldehyde formation rate. When the reaction temperature ranged between 620 and 700 °C, the corresponding formaldehyde formation rate of the catalyst decreased rapidly with increasing V loading. This may be due to the gradual aggregation of isolated VO4 species into oligomeric V–O–V species as the V content increased, resulting in a decrease in activity per unit V atom. However, the consumption rate of methane gradually increased with the temperature, as shown in Fig. 8C. At lower temperatures, a lower methane consumption rate was observed for all catalysts, which may be due to the poor ability of the present catalysts to activate methane at low temperatures. As the temperature increased, all catalysts except 8 V/MSN exhibited higher methane consumption rates. Based on the Arrhenius equation, the E a value shows a decreasing trend with the increase of V content, indicating that catalysts with high V loading have stronger methane activation ability (Fig. 8D), which is consistent with the activity evaluation results. However, the difference in E a values among catalysts with different V loading amounts was not significant, indicating that the degrees of polymerization of the V species were similar. This may be the main reason for the presence of a large number of active sites for selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde and CO on all the studied catalysts. Fig. 9A and B show the methane oxidation rate as a function of the CH4 and O2 pressures, respectively. The rate of methane oxidation exhibited a linear increase with methane pressure, indicating methane could be weakly adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. However, the rate of methane oxidation increases with the increase of oxygen pressure (5–25 kPa; 670 °C), and further increase in pressure has little effect on the rate of methane oxidation, possibly due to the complete oxidation of VOx species on the catalysts surface at this time. The above results indicate that the reaction on the surface of V/MSN catalyst may follow the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. The isothermal IOE results (Fig. 9C) showed that the oxygen species on the 2 V/MSN catalyst had poor 18O isotope exchange ability. However, when CH4 and 18O2 were simultaneously introduced on the surface of the catalysts, a slight increase of the signal intensity for 18O16O and 18O2 was detected. Therefore, it can be inferred that gas-phase oxygen plays an important role in CH4 activation, and the V/MSN catalysts may follow the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism under reaction conditions. Based on the results of the above experiments, the reaction mechanism over different VOx species is shown in Fig. 9D. 3.4 Reaction mechanisms for composite catalysts In order to investigate the relationship between active site structures and reaction products on different catalysts, CH4-TPSR experiments were conducted on catalysts with different V contents. Fig. 10 provides a detailed description of the products formed in the CH4-TPSR tests, which included HCHO, CO, and CO2. CO2 was the only product formed on all samples below 300 °C, and the main reaction product observed at low temperature (T < 550 °C). These results indicate that catalysts with different V loadings had lower methane activation temperatures, but the oxygen species on their surface mainly led to deep methane oxidation at low temperatures. Among them, a stronger formaldehyde signal was observed on the 2 V/MSN catalyst with isolated VO4 species, and the temperature of formaldehyde production was lower. At the same time, the CO2 signal significantly decreased, while the signal of the CO (selective oxidation product) significantly increased with increasing temperature, accompanied by a decrease in the formaldehyde signal. This is consistent with the activity evaluation results, suggesting that CO was the main product of the further oxidation of formaldehyde at high temperatures on the 2 V/MSN catalyst in the absence of gas-phase oxygen, and the isolated VO4 species on the 2 V/MSN catalysts effectively inhibited the deep oxidation of the product HCHO to CO2. Therefore, a high formaldehyde selectivity was achieved for the 2 V/MSN catalyst (as shown in Fig. 7). Interestingly, under the same experimental conditions (absence of gas-phase and chemisorbed oxygen), weaker formaldehyde signals were only observed at 530 °C on the 8 V/MSN catalyst. However, significant CO2 and CO signals appeared with increasing temperature, likely due to additional deep oxidation reactions induced by oxygen on the oligomeric V–O–V species under gaseous oxygen-free conditions. Therefore, the 8 V/MSN catalyst did have a stronger methane activation ability (as shown in Fig. 7), which resulted in a higher CH4 conversion throughout the entire temperature range. The above experimental results indicate that the oxygen species on the catalysts participated in the selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde in the absence of gaseous oxygen. However, oxygen species on VOx centers with high dispersion and low polymerization would not be conducive to the selective oxidation of CH4 to formaldehyde, but would result in the production of CO and CO2, which is deeper oxidation product. In order to further verify the relationship between the detected products and the active sites shown by the CH4-TPSR results, in situ Raman spectroscopy ( Fig. 11) was used to characterize the changes in the active sites under methane atmosphere. Characteristic peaks attributed to VOx species were found at 930 and 1030 cm−1 in the spectra of the 2 V/MSN and 8 V/MSN catalysts. The VO stretching vibration band corresponding to isolated VOx species in tetrahedral coordination (VO4) was detected at 1030 cm−1. The Raman bands at 930 cm−1 were assigned to the V–O–V bonds of the oligomeric VOx species. The analysis of the above characterization and activity evaluation data shows that a higher density of active sites (isolated VO4) will oxidize formaldehyde to CO, while the more abundant oligomeric VOx species will accelerate the generation of CO2. The in situ Raman spectra results obtained under methane atmosphere also confirmed these results: the characteristic peak intensity corresponding to oligomeric VOx species (930 cm−1) significantly decreased in the temperature range of 100–400 °C, suggesting that oligomeric VOx species were the first to participate in the reaction at low temperatures. In combination with the CH4-TPSR results, it can be inferred that CO2 was the main product in this temperature range, further confirming that oligomeric VOx species were the active sites for the deep oxidation of methane to CO2. Interestingly, a greater consumption of isolated VO4 species on the catalyst was observed within the reaction temperature range of 500–700 °C. Moreover, the activity evaluation results revealed that the catalyst achieved higher selectivity for formaldehyde and CO, confirming that the isolated VO4 species are the active sites for the formation of formaldehyde and CO. The MSN support prepared by the emulsion method has a high specific surface area and a radial pore structure, which facilitates the dispersion of active components and the diffusion of reactants and products. Similarly, the grafting method can anchor V species on the catalyst surface, thereby producing V/MSN catalysts with isolated and highly dispersed VOx species. The results of Raman spectroscopy, UV-Vis DRS, and other characterizations confirmed that no V2O5 phase was found on the surface of the catalyst even at the highest V loading (8 V/MSN). The VOx species on the catalyst surface were mainly present as isolated VO4, and some oligomeric VOx were presented on the samples with relatively high loading amounts of V. The presence of isolated VO4 sites is a key factor for avoiding the continuous oxidation of formaldehyde, however, the number of isolated active sites also limits the formaldehyde selectivity. The analysis of the structure–activity relationship of the V/MSN catalysts revealed that the isolated VO4 species serve as active sites for the formation of formaldehyde and CO, but the number of isolated VO4 active sites should be moderate. An excessive number of active sites will increase the probability of secondary reactions between the generated formaldehyde and the active sites, further oxidizing formaldehyde to CO. Furthermore, the oligomeric VOx species serve as active sites for the deep oxidation reaction of reactants and target products to CO2. 4 Conclusion A series of V/MSN catalysts were successfully prepared using the organic metal grafting method. The characterization results such as XRD and Raman spectra confirm that the VOx species on the catalyst surface mainly exist in the form of highly dispersed separated VO4 species on the catalyst with low V loading, and some of these species aggregate into oligomeric V-O-V for the samples with high V loading (8 V/MSN). Based on the characterization results of isothermal IOE and CH4-TPSR, it was found that the reaction on the catalysts may mainly follow the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. The structure-activity relationship analysis found that the isolated VO4 species serve as the selective oxidation active sites for the formation of formaldehyde and CO, while the oligomeric V-O-V species serve as active sites for the deep oxidation to generate CO2. Moreover, the number of isolated VO4 active sites should be moderate. An excessive number of VO4 sites will increase the probability of secondary reactions between the generated formaldehyde and the active sites, resulting in the formation of CO. Moreover, the total selectivity of formaldehyde and CO on all catalysts exceeded 83.6 %. The isolated VO4 species in the 2 V/MSN catalyst achieved high selectivity for formaldehyde, with a maximum yield of 3.7 % at 670 °C. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of methane to value-added C1 chemicals (e.g., HCHO and CO) is a crucial process in the chemical industry. Recent studies indicate that the generation of highly dispersed isolated active sites is crucial for improving the performance in the selective oxidation of methane and studying the corresponding structure–activity relationship. Therefore, we used mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN) as supports and utilized grafting method to prepare catalysts with more selective oxidation active centers (isolated VO4). The study found that isolated VO4 centers are the active sites for the selective oxidation of methane to formaldehyde, and CO is the product of further oxidation of formaldehyde. The total selectivity of formaldehyde and CO on all catalysts is higher than 83.6 %. Among them, the highly dispersed and isolated VO4 tetrahedral active centers on the 2 V/MSN catalyst could stably convert methane to formaldehyde, achieving the highest formaldehyde yield of 3.7 % at 670 °C.
